awd_titl_txt: LTREB:  Nutrients and climate as drivers of carbon sequestration and ecosystem metabolism in a shallow coastal ecosystem during recovery from nitrogen pollution
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrogen pollution is one of the largest threats to the ecological integrity of coastal bays, leading to the degradation of two-thirds of these systems in the US.  Shallow coastal bays are found along much of the east coast, and are particularly vulnerable to the effects of excess nitrogen, which can lead to algal blooms, low dissolved oxygen, and loss of high-habitat quality seagrasses.  This research will examine the recovery of a shallow bay as nitrogen inputs are greatly reduced without any concomitant change in inputs of other nutrients and pollutants, making it perhaps the first such study in the US.  The site, West Falmouth Harbor on Cape Cod (MA), has received high levels of nitrogen inputs for the past 15 years, due to contamination of incoming groundwater by a sewage treatment plant, causing poor water quality and habitat degradation.  The nitrogen contamination has now been cleaned up, and so nitrogen inputs entering the harbor will be 3-fold less than in the past.  To date, relatively few coastal bays have recovered from excessive nitrogen inputs, so this study will provide information on the rate of recovery and extent of restoration of habitat quality that is critical to better manage and protect these valuable coastal resources.   

While most coastal scientists believe nitrogen is the primary cause of coastal eutrophication, this remains debated.  This study will provide important insights as to not only whether nitrogen is the controlling nutrient, but if so, why.  One hypothesis is that a large net import of phosphorus from deeper coastal water helps maintain N limitation. If so, net phosphorus import should decline as primary production (and resultant demand for phosphorus) declines.  The research will also explore the relationship of carbon storage to net ecosystem production, testing the hypothesis that lower nitrogen inputs will shift the ecosystem towards greater heterotrophy. Will the harbor continue to store carbon, by importing more carbon than the net amount respired?  These questions will be addressed by measuring rates of primary production and ecosystem respiration from diel changes in dissolved oxygen and pH, seagrass extent and biomass elemental composition, and by measuring the exchanges of nitrogen, phosphorus, and carbon between the harbor and the deeper adjacent coastal waters of Buzzards Bay, MA.  Results will be compared with 12 years of data taken during the high nitrogen loading period, and will thus provide a strong picture of the recovery trajectory of the system.

por.por_cntn:
This LTREB award funded our study of nitrogen pollution in a coastal marine ecosystem, West Falmouth Harbor (MA), from 2017 through 2024, building on our earlier research in this system since 2004 funded by NSF and Woods Hole Sea Grant. A poor policy decision by the local town government provided an ideal opportunity to study the consequences of nitrogen pollution in this shallow, seagrass-dominated system.  Beginning in the 1980s, the town built a new sewer system and disposed of the effluent in the watershed of West Falmouth Harbor. This resulted in a large input of nitrogen to the harbor, as effluent slowly moved through the groundwater.  Phosphorus and other elements from the wastewater are retained in the aquifer’s soils.  The result has been an (inadvertent) experiment in which nitrogen inputs to the harbor increased by more than 3-fold, with no increase in phosphorus. Because of the slow movement of the waste plume through the aquifer, nitrogen inputs into the harbor only started to increase as of 2003.  We believe this is the only whole-ecosystem study conducted anywhere in the world that has evaluated the consequences of an addition of nitrogen alone on ecosystem functioning in a shallow system.  Our study began in 2004, within one year of the increased nitrogen.

 

One major finding is that primary production is limited by nitrogen, not phosphorus. This finding aligns with a large body of other evidence on nutrient limitation and eutrophication in coastal marine ecosystems, but contrasts with the prevalence of phosphorus as a limiting factor and driver of eutrophication in productive freshwater lakes. Until recently, some prominent freshwater ecologists have challenged the idea that coastal marine ecosystems behave differently than lakes, and are limited by nitrogen rather than phosphorus.  They pointed to whole-lake experiments that demonstrated phosphorus limitation, and noted the absence of such whole-ecosystem experiments in coastal marine systems, which they held would be the only definitive source of evidence on nutrient limitation.  The West Falmouth Harbor experiment has now provided that previously missing coastal experiment, fully establishing that nitrogen limitation can occur in coastal marine ecosystems.

 

One difference between coastal marine ecosystems and lakes that can make nitrogen limitation more likely is the import of phosphorus from coastal oceans. In West Falmouth Harbor, we demonstrated that much of the phosphorus in the ecosystem comes from these ocean sources. Without this input of phosphorus, phosphorus would have been more likely to have become limiting. Of great interest, our data show that the amount of phosphorus in the coastal waters that enter West Falmouth with tidal waters has declined substantially over time, although the inputs are still sufficient to provide met the needs of seagrasses and algae in the system, keeping the system nitrogen-limited.  We are unsure of the cause of the decrease in phosphorus in coastal waters but hypothesize it may be related to climate-driven changes in the physical circulation of water on the continental shelf, influencing the flux of nutrients from deep Atlantic Ocean waters to Buzzards Bay, the coastal waters adjacent to West Falmouth.

 

When we started our investigations in West Falmouth in 2004, we had hypothesized that nitrogen fixation by microorganisms living on the surface of seagrass leaves would decrease as the external nitrogen inputs increased. This nitrogen fixation converts the molecular N2 that comprises most of the Earth’s atmosphere into biologically available nitrogen. If our hypothesis had been correct, the decrease might have partially mitigated the increasing nitrogen pollution. However, in contrast to our expectation, our research demonstrated a large increase in nitrogen fixation in the ecosystem over time, further increasing the overall availability of nitrogen and contributing to decreased water quality.  The reason is that as West Falmouth became more eutrophic, sediment quality declined and concentrations of toxic soluble sulfides in the sediment increased. This adversely affected animals that had been grazing on the microorganisms on seagrasses. Consequently, the mass of microorganisms and their rates of nitrogen fixation increased.

 

The nitrogen pollution in West Falmouth Harbor led to the complete die-off of seagrasses in one part of the system in 2011.  Surprisingly, this appears to have had little effect on the overall rate of primary production in the ecosystem, presumably because the production by seagrasses was replaced by production by bottom-dwelling micro- and macro-algae.  Unlike many aquatic ecosystems, phytoplankton contribute rather little to primary production in this harbor:  the water residence time is quite short, averaging one day or so, and phytoplankton are flushed out of the system as quickly as they grow.

 

Because of improvements in the treatment of sewage at the wastewater facility, our research shows that nitrogen inputs to West Falmouth Harbor have declined by 25% since 2010.  Over this same time period, rates of gross primary production in the harbor declined by 10%.
